title: Hurwitz's theorem (composition algebras)
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, Hurwitz's theorem is a theorem of <a href="Adolf%20Hurwitz">Adolf Hurwitz</a> (1859–1919), published posthumously in 1923, solving the <a href="Hurwitz%20problem">Hurwitz problem</a> for finite-dimensional <a href="unital%20algebra">unital</a> <a href="real%20numbers">real</a> <a href="non-associative%20algebra">non-associative algebra</a>s endowed with a <a href="positive-definite%20quadratic%20form">positive-definite quadratic form</a>. The theorem states that if the <a href="quadratic%20form">quadratic form</a> defines a <a href="homomorphism">homomorphism</a> into the <a href="positive%20real%20numbers">positive real numbers</a> on the non-zero part of the algebra, then the algebra must be <a href="Isomorphism">isomorphic</a> to the <a href="real%20number">real number</a>s, the <a href="complex%20number">complex number</a>s, the <a href="quaternion">quaternion</a>s, or the <a href="octonion">octonion</a>s. Such algebras, sometimes called Hurwitz algebras, are examples of <a href="composition%20algebra">composition algebra</a>s.
The theory of composition algebras has subsequently been generalized to arbitrary quadratic forms and arbitrary <a href="field%20%28mathematics%29">fields</a>. Hurwitz's theorem implies that multiplicative formulas for sums of squares can only occur in 1, 2, 4 and 8 dimensions, a result originally proved by Hurwitz in 1898. It is a special case of the <a href="Hurwitz%20problem">Hurwitz problem</a>, solved also in . Subsequent proofs of the restrictions on the dimension have been given by using the <a href="representation%20theory%20of%20finite%20groups">representation theory of finite groups</a> and by and using <a href="Clifford%20algebra">Clifford algebra</a>s. Hurwitz's theorem has been applied in <a href="algebraic%20topology">algebraic topology</a> to problems on <a href="vector%20fields%20on%20spheres%23Radon%E2%80%93Hurwitz%20numbers">vector fields on spheres</a> and the <a href="homotopy%20group">homotopy group</a>s of the <a href="classical%20group">classical group</a>s and in <a href="quantum%20mechanics">quantum mechanics</a> to the <a href="Symmetric%20cone%23Simple%20Euclidean%20Jordan%20algebras">classification of simple Jordan algebras</a>.
